thread.title: Online petition for second EU referendum signed by 60,000 from the North
thread.title_full: Online petition for second EU referendum signed by 60,000 from the North

author: Mike Kelly
title: Online petition for second EU referendum signed by 60,000 from the North
text:
Online petition for second EU referendum signed by 60,000 from the North 18:05, 25 Jun 2016 More than 1.7m people nationally sign online petition calling for another EU referendum Shares Get daily news by email The North East region European Union referendum count at Sunderland 
Nearly 60,000 people from the North have signed an online petition calling for a second EU referendum . 
They are among 1,750,000 nationally who had signed it by 5pm on Saturday with the number growing by the hour. 
It was set up by William Oliver Healey, and states: “We the undersigned call upon HM Government to implement a rule that if the Remain or Leave vote is less than 60%, based on a turnout less than 75%, there should be another referendum.” 
The House of Commons Petitions committee will now be forced to consider staging a debate in Parliament on the proposal. 
Their next meeting is on Tuesday after MPs return from a mini-recess, although it might have to wait until the following week to be discussed. 
The petition and demonstrations in London reflect the anger among the 16m people who voted to remain in the EU, who were overwhelmingly young voters. 
Three out of every four voters in the 18 to 24 age group voted for Remain. Meanwhile more than half - or 56% - of 25 to 49-year-olds also backed the pro-EU option, according to initial estimates of the vote breakdown by YouGov. 
It is they who may have to live with the consequences the longest who seemed most disappointed with the result. 
Meanwhile it was older voters who were most keen on Brexit. 
Newcastle Central MP Chi Onwurah expressed her sympathy with the petition signers and felt what the EU did for the UK didn’t get a fair hearing. 
She said: “For the last 40 years politicians of all parties have been blaming the EU for everything from the shape of cucumbers to the demise of the coal and steel industry. 
“We had a three month campaign to turn around 40 years of negativity and it proved an uphill task.” More on the EU Referendum
